title: SA winemakers worried over adding bottles to 10c Container Deposit Scheme | ABC NEWS
description: Small wine businesses are worried about the additional administrative and financial costs of expanding the Container Deposit Scheme to include wine bottles.  They want a threshold or exemptions for smaller businesses, as well as a streamlined national reporting system. title: Unique rehab centre paves the way for healing on-country | ABC NEWS
description: With the Northern Territory prison population sitting at a record high, a group of Aboriginal men on Groote Eylandt are breaking ground as the first participants in a new, on-country residential rehab program. The Anindilyakwa Healing Centre opened earlier this year as part of the former government's Local Decision Making agreement with the Groote community. The centre has drawn praise from Anindilyakwa elders, locals and participants, attracting interest from communities across the NT. However, with the Territory government scrapping the Local Decision Making policy earlier this year, there are concerns the centre's success will be difficult to recreate. By Joseph Hathaway-Wilson for Stateline NT.   Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: US-backed Gaza proposal & Palestinian statehood set to be discussed at the UN | ABC NEWS
description: The US is seeking support from the UN Security Council for its post-war plan for Gaza. Israel wants the US to close the door on Palestinian statehood as part of the plan. Donald Trump's 20-point draft proposal includes a vague reference to recognising a Palestinian state in the future. Middle East correspondent Matthew Doran reports from Jerusalem. title: Are Trump’s tariffs wrecking the US economy? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Donald Trump’s been all over the place with his tariffs, but the US is now bringing in billions of dollars in revenue from them.   Months since the tariffs were first announced and after dire warnings from economists, how is the American economy really faring?    Today, Penny Goldberg, professor of economics at Yale University, on why the US economy hasn’t yet seen a major downturn and the dark clouds in the longer term outlook.    Featured:   Pinelopi Koujianou Goldberg, Professor of Economics at Yale University and fmr Chief Economist at the World Bank Group

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene hits back after Trump labels her a ‘traitor’ | ABC NEWS
description: Marjorie Taylor Greene has hit back after Donald Trump called her a “traitor” and withdrew his support for her after the Republican Congresswoman called for the release of Epstein files. Once a staunch ally of Trump, Taylor Greene has signalled a shift away from the Republican Party in recent months over several key issues including the government shutdown, US involvement in foreign affairs and Epstein. title: Laos methanol poisoning survivor's key message for tourists travelling to SE Asia | ABC NEWS
description: Laos methanol poisoning survivor Bethany Clarke has co-founded an awareness and education campaign in tribute to her best friend, Simone White. Simone was among six people, including two Australians who died after drinking methanol-tainted alcohol in Vang Vieng, Laos.  Clarke is urging tourists travelling to South East Asia to avoid drinking spirits and instead opt for sealed drinks from a bottle or can. title: Cattle, Water, and Power: Life on the Macquarie Marshes | Landline | ABC News
description: The Macquarie Marshes in New South Wales is an internationally recognised wetland system that's a vital breeding site for waterbirds. It's also been home to graziers for generations. Irrigators and regional towns rely on the river that feeds the marshlands as well. But Landline's Kerry Staight found there are questions about whether enough water is getting through to the fragile landscape.  Landline is a national rural affairs television program covering stories from rural and regional Australia. Our team of journalists offers an unrivalled insight into the issues, people, business and history of Australian farming. We'll take you from dusty outback stations to beautiful dairy country, and everywhere in between. title: Thousands take part in half-marathon up Hobart's Kunanyi / Mt Wellington | ABC NEWS
description: It pitches itself as the world's hardest half-marathon, with more than 5,000 competitors taking part in the challenge of running up Hobart's kunanyi/Mt. Wellington, for the 30th Point to Pinnacle.  It was a feat that came with a record crowd, record times, and more than a million dollars raised for charity.
